corpus.74ea9f80-e763-459e-bcc3-df3530cb8051:
1) Tooth fracture
Classified by failure mechanisms, we have: fatigue fracture—occurs when a cantilever beam is subjected to fluctuating bending stresses or stress concentrations, causing fatigue cracks to propagate from the tensile side at the tooth root until final fracture; overload fracture—resulting from excessively high impact loads or short-term, severe overloading; and wear-induced fracture, where severe tooth wear reduces the gear's static strength, ultimately leading to failure.
There are two forms of fracture in terms of morphology: complete fracture and partial fracture.
From a design perspective, the gear teeth should undergo calculations to assess their root bending strength. From a manufacturing standpoint, increasing the radius of the fillet at the tooth root, reducing surface roughness, applying surface hardening treatments, and minimizing machining-induced damage on the tooth flank can all help enhance the tooth's resistance to fatigue failure. Additionally, improving the stiffness of the shaft and supports—and ideally eliminating any uneven distribution of loads—can significantly reduce the likelihood of localized tooth fractures.

② The setting current adjustment cam (or adjusting screw) has been turned to an improper position, causing the normally closed contac t to open; alternatively, the normally closed contact may have burned out, resulting in an open control circuit when the thermal relay is connected. For the first issue, you can op en the cover of the thermal relay, inspect the cam mechanism responsible for its operation, and adjust it to the correct position. In the second case, you’ll need to replace the co ntact along with the associated spring.
③ The wiring screws in the main or control circuit of the thermal relay were not tightened properly; over time, they loosened, resulting in  an open circuit in either the main or control circuit. Simply check and tighten the wiring screws to resolve the issue.
(2) Thermal relay malfunction.
Thermal relay malfunction ref ers to the phenomenon where the relay trips even though the motor is not overloaded.
① Since the motor protected by the thermal relay is frequently started, the heating element is  repeatedly subjected to the impact of inrush current.
corpus.85c2dc89-aed0-4deb-8e67-4e29b49e2b98:
Maintenance method: Inspect or replace the overflow valve.
3. Hydraulic System Temperature Rise Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance
Typically, the normal operating temperature for hydraulic systems is between 40 and 60°C; exceeding 60°C can negatively impact the system.
Causes of overheating failures in hydraulic systems
Hydraulic systems frequently experience overheating during operation. Analysis reveals that the main causes of overheating are as follows:
In various aspects.
(1) The hydraulic system design is unreasonable.
① The hydraulic system's oil tank has been designed with too small a capacity and insufficient heat dissipation area, and no coolin g device has been incorporated—or if one is present, its capacity is inadequate.
② The selected valve components are undersized, leading to excessively high oil flow velocities thr ough the valves and increased pressure losses, which in turn cause overheating. For instance, if an overflow valve is too small, or if the directional control valve in a differenti al circuit is sized solely based on the pump’s flow rate, this issue can occur.
corpus.093e165c-409f-458f-a850-2940c012d39d:
The inertial forces generated by high-speed hydraulic actuators can also cause hydraulic shocks within the system. For instance, when industrial robotic arms or the slewing motors of hydraulic excavator turntables brake or reverse direction—resulting in the sudden closure of the oil discharge lines—the rotating mechanisms, still moving due to inertia, continue to spin, leading to a sharp increase in pressure and triggering a hydraulic shock.
(3) Components exhibit sluggish response actions. In hydraulic systems, certain components’ delayed or unresponsive behavior can also lead to hydraulic shocks. For instance, a pressure-limiting variable hydraulic pump may fail to promptly reduce its displacement when pressure rises, resulting in pressure surges. Similarly, if the relief valve cannot open quickly enough, it may cause excessive pressure overshoot, both of which can trigger pressure shocks.
2) Troubleshooting Hydraulic Shock Faults
(1) Maximize the time required for valve closure and braking/reversing of moving components.

A Tutorial on Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Electro-Mechanical Systems Involving Bubble Formation
22
When bubbles are forced to collapse, their rapid implosion—at speeds as high a s 250 m/s—immediately generates an enormous impact force and extremely high temperatures. Under the combined effects of this intense force and extreme heat, localized liquids can e ject tiny jets of liquid outward. This phenomenon is known as cavitation.
If a bubble collapses right at the surface of a component, the surface itself comes under direct impact from these microjets. Over time, as bubbles repeatedly form and burst in close proximity to the surface, the material on the component’s surface is continuously bombarded by these high-speed liquid jets. This relentless erosion eventually leads to fatigue, causing the material to gradually flake off—initially forming small pitting marks that, over time, expand into a sponge-like, foam-like texture. This process is commonly referred to as cavitation damage.
Cavitation is a relatively complex destructive phenomenon that involves not only mechanical effects but also chemical and electrochemical processes.

1.2.6 Equipment Fault Diagnosis Technology
When equipment malfunctions, certain characteristics change accordingly, leading to vari ations in mechanical, thermal, acoustic, and electromagnetic physical and chemical parameters—each carrying distinct types of information. By capturing these altered indicators, de tecting the underlying signals and patterns, and analyzing their causes and anomalies, fault diagnosis technology enables us to pinpoint the location, nature, and severity of the f ailure, as well as forecast future issues, assess damage conditions, make informed decisions, eliminate potential hazards, and ultimately prevent accidents from occurring. This is  precisely what fault diagnosis technology aims to achieve.

1.2.7 Patterns of Failure Occurrence
Mechanical and electrical equipment failures exhibit two notable characteristics: first, the likelihood of failure increases as the equipment ages; second, failures occur randomly, making it difficult to predict the exact timing of any given failure. Consequently, over the equipment's lifespan, the probability of a failure can be expressed using statistical methods. The failure rate, denoted by ( \lambda(t) ), represents the conditional probability that a failure will occur within the infinitesimal time interval ( dt ), given that no failure has yet happened up to time ( t ).

The hazards posed by brittle fracture in metals are significant, second only to those  associated with fatigue failure.
Fatigue Fracture
The fracture phenomenon that occurs in metal parts after being subjected to a certain number of cyclic loads or alternating stresses is known as fatigue failure. In fact, 80% of fractures in mechanical components during use are caused by fatigue.

5.7 Common Faults of Electromagnetic Flow Meters
Common faults in electromagnetic flowmeters can result either from damage to the instrument's internal components or from improper selection, incorrect installation, adverse environmental conditions, and fluid characteristics—leading to issues such as display fluctuations, reduced accuracy, or even complete instrument failure. These faults are generally categorized into two types: those that occur during installation and commissioning (commissioning-phase faults) and those that arise during normal operation (operation-phase faults).
1. Debugging Phase Faults
Debugging-phase failures typically occur during the instrument installation and commissioning stage, but once resolved, they generally do not reappear under the same conditions afterward. Common debugging-phase faults are usually caused by improper installation, environmental interference, and the influence of fluid characteristics.

7. System Leak Fault Diagnosis and Repair
System leaks are categorized into internal and external leaks, and depending on the severity of the  leak, they can manifest in various forms, such as oil film scraping, seepage, dripping, and spraying. Oil film scraping occurs between relatively moving components, like sliding o r reciprocating pairs in rotating parts. Seepage typically happens at the junctions of end covers and valve plates. Dripping is most common around pipe fittings and connections. Sp raying, on the other hand, often results from broken pipes or improperly installed seals.

Additionally, the electro-hydraulic directional valve offers two options for controlling the oil supply to its control circuit: internal oil supply and external oil supply. In the case of internal oil supply, the control circuit draws pressure oil directly from the main oil line via port P—this is known as internal control. For external oil supply, an independent oil source is typically required, which is referred to as external control. Similarly, the return path for the control circuit can also follow either an internal return (internal leakage) or an external return (external leakage), as illustrated in Figure 3.12(b).

The extent of the elastic aftereffect depends on factors such as the material’s properties, the magnitude of the stress, its initial state, and the temperature. Specifically, the more non-uniform the metal’s microstructure, the greater the applied stress, and the higher the temperature, the more pronounced the elastic aftereffect will be. Typically, after straightening, shaft-like components tend to bend again after some time—this is a clear manifestation of the elastic aftereffect. To eliminate this phenomenon, one effective method is to perform prolonged tempering, which ensures that residual stresses are completely relieved within a short period.

corpus.49610be8-2f2b-4e09-a3dc-0db4d150391d:
Electroplating repair technology is a widely used technique for restoring component dimensions under low-temperature conditions. Compared to welding repair methods, it avoids the various issues caused by localized high temperatures, while the bond strength between the electroplated layer and the substrate is nearly equivalent to that achieved with welding repairs. This technique leverages the principle of electrolysis: metal ions from the plating solution are reduced into metallic atoms, which then deposit onto the metal surface, forming a repair layer with strong adhesion and precise thickness control. Common applications include chrome plating, low-temperature iron plating, and brush plating.
8. Thermal Spraying and Spray Welding Repair Method
Thermal Spray Repair Technology
Thermal spraying technology involves using a heat source to melt or partially melt the coating material, which is then sprayed onto a pre-treated su bstrate surface at a controlled speed, forming a coating that bonds firmly to the base material of the workpiece.

Since brazed joints typically exhibit lower strength compared to other welding techniques, brazing is generally recommended for repairing cracks and fractures in components that do not require high structural integrity. Additionally, designing and selecting an appropriate joint configuration is crucial to enhance the overall strength of the assembly. Brazing is especially well-suited for addressing localized defects—such as abrasions or scratches—on low-speed moving parts.
7. Electroplating Repair Technology
Electroplating is a process that uses electrolysis to deposit metal onto the surface of a part, forming a metallic coating. The electroplating repair method not only restores the dimensions of worn parts but also enhances their surface quality—particularly improving wear resistance and corrosion resistance.

Corrosion products such as Fe₂O₃ or Fe₃O₄ typically form a protective film that coats the metal surface. During friction, Chapter 1: Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Mechanical and Electrical Equipment
21
After the surface oxide film is worn away, the friction surface quickly reacts with the oxidizing medium, forming a new oxide layer that is subsequently removed during the friction  process. This cyclical process ultimately leads to metal corrosion. A key characteristic of oxidative wear is the presence of uniform, fine grooves aligned along the sliding direc tion on the friction surface, accompanied by reddish-brown flaky Fe₂O₃ or grayish-black filamentous Fe₃O₄ debris.

Causes of Hydraulic Oil Contamination
More than 75% of hydraulic system failures are caused by hydraulic oil contamination. In hydraulic systems, the oil tank is often the primary source of fluid contamination. Many tanks suffer from design and manufacturing flaws—most commonly, "closed" tank designs that are poorly engineered. For instance, seals are frequently omitted at connections and pipe joints, allowing contaminants to seep into the tank. Once contaminated, the oil circulates through the hydraulic system, accelerating wear, corrosion, and blockages in critical components—and ultimately leading to system failure. In recent years, Chapter 3 has focused extensively on diagnosing and repairing hydraulic system faults.
75
Manufacturers have conducted numerous valuable explorations and practical efforts in optimizing fuel tank structural design to minimize or eliminate contaminants from entering the tank. For instance, the now-common fully enclosed tank design features a single vent hole that remains connected to the atmosphere, while the rest of the tank is completely sealed. All connection points and pipe joints are equipped with rigorously designed sealing mechanisms.

Take metal cutting machine tools as an example: the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established various precision testing standards for different types of machine tools, along with general guidelines for machine tool accuracy verification. Similarly, China has developed its own standards that are either equivalent to or closely aligned with international benchmarks. These standards specify the inspection items, criteria, methods, and tolerances for machine tool accuracy—serving as the fundamental basis for conducting precision tests. Currently, machine tool maintenance is carried out based on both geometric and operational precision standards during acceptance procedures.
Inspection of Machine Tool Geometric Accuracy
Geometric accuracy of machine tools refers to the precision of the components that ultimately affect the machine's operational accuracy. It encompasses individual accuracies of basic structural elements, positional accuracy between various parts, as well as motion accuracy, positioning accuracy, indexing accuracy, and transmission chain accuracy. Typically, geometric accuracy checks are performed while the machine tool is stationary. Before conducting these inspections, it’s essential to first ensure proper installation and leveling.

1.2.4 Use of Mechanical and Elect rical Equipment
During operation, equipment's technical condition changes—and its performance gradually declines—due to various forces acting upon it, as well as factors such as en vironmental conditions, usage methods, operational guidelines, and the duration of use. To effectively manage these changes in technical condition and slow down the decline in equi pment performance, the most critical measure is to ensure the equipment is used properly and correctly.
Maintenance of mechanical and electrical equipment is a crucial method for i mproving utilization and ensuring its functionality—it consists of two forms: daily maintenance and periodic maintenance.
Daily maintenance is primarily carried out by operators of  mechanical and electrical equipment—conducting pre-shift inspections and post-shift cleaning to ensure that the equipment remains in optimal technical condition.
Regular maintenan ce, also known as Level 1 care, is carried out by operators with assistance from maintenance personnel.

1) Signal Acquisition
During operation, equipment inevitably experiences changes in various quantities such as force, heat, vibration, and energy, generating a wide range of distinct information. Depending on specific diagnostic needs, it is crucial to select signals that accurately reflect the equipment's operational status—such as vibration, pressure, or temperature—since these signals are typically captured using different types of sensors.
2) Signal Processing
This is the process of classifying and processing the collected signals to extract features that accurately represent the machine's characteristics—also known as feature extraction. For example, transforming a vibration signal from the time domain to the frequency domain for spectral analysis is part of this process.
3) State Recognition
The device's characteristic parameters, obtained after signal processing, are compared with the specified allowable or discriminant parameters to determine the device's condition.

2.4.4 Assembly of Rolling Bearings
Rolling bearings consist of an inner ring, outer ring, rolling elements, and a cage—they are the bearing components that enable relative motion between the shaft and the bearing housing through rolling friction. Rolling bearings offer advantages such as low friction coefficients, high efficiency, compact axial dimensions, and ease of assembly and disassembly, making them widely used in various types of machinery and equipment. As standardized components mass-produced by specialized factories, rolling bearings come with predetermined inner diameters, outer diameters, and axial widths at the time of manufacture. Consequently, the inner ring of a rolling bearing serves as the reference hole, while the outer ring acts as the reference shaft. 3.2.9 Fault Diagnosis and Repair of Pressure Relays
Structure and Working Principle of Pressure Relays
As shown in Figure 3.17, a pressure relay is a hydraulic-electrical conversion component that uses fluid pressure to open or close electrical contacts. It generates an electrical signal when the oil pressure reaches the set pressure level, triggering the operation of electrical components and enabling automatic control of the hydraulic system—or serving as a safety protection mechanism. The pressure relay consists of two main parts: a pressure-to-displacement conversion element and a microswitch. Based on their structure and operating principles, pressure relays can be classified into four types: plunger-type, spring-tube type, diaphragm-type, and bellows-type, with the plunger-type being the most widely used. Figure 3.17 illustrates the structure and appearance of a plunger-type pressure relay.

Hydraulic oil is a critical medium for maintaining the system's proper operation, and preserving its high qua lity is essential to ensuring optimal transmission performance and efficiency. corpus.8686fda3-acec-49d5-bbda-3fb6dcce5b5b:
2) Condition Monitoring and Maintenance
This is a preventive maintenance approach based on the equipment's tec hnical condition, carried out precisely when needed. It relies on condition monitoring and advanced diagnostic techniques to track the gradual deterioration of equipment over time.  By leveraging highly predictive insights, this method allows for timely scheduling of preventive maintenance activities, which is why it’s also referred to as  "predictive maintenance. "
At its core, this maintenance strategy integrates comprehensive data from various sources—such as inspections, routine upkeep, operational use, and repair activities—especially insights gained from diagnostics and monitoring. Through rigorous statistical analysis, it accurately assesses the extent of equipment degradation, identifies specific areas where failures may occur (or are likely to occur), and predicts trends in the equipment’s overall technical condition. Armed with this information, operators can then determine the most appropriate type of maintenance intervention.
By doing so, organizations gain full control over maintenance activities, ensuring thorough preparation before repairs begin. Moreover, this approach enables seamless coordination with production schedules, maximizing equipment utilization while simultaneously extending the lifespan of critical components.

corpus.937cd77f-12e3-4a25-ba9d-a48d8af63a1e:
2) Causes of Creep Failure Due to Seals and Maintenance Measures
Hydraulic cylinders are significantly affected by seal rings when it comes to the phenomenon of creep. In most cases, the first step should be to check whether the piston rod support seals and piston seals are tightened too much. If creep occurs when the hydraulic cylinder's movement speed drops below 5 mm/s, no other solutions will work effectively.
When selecting seals, care should be taken to ensure proper performance. To eliminate creeping, the seal material must have a minimal difference between its dynamic and static friction coefficients. Additionally, the sealing design itself should minimize resistance while maximizing rigidity; after being subjected to tensile forces, it should exhibit low elongation. Ideally, the sealing material would possess negative friction characteristics—meaning that as sliding speed increases, so does the resistance. For instance, seals made from leather or polytetrafluoroethylene are well-suited for low-speed applications in hydraulic cylinders. However, V-shaped seals containing only nitrile rubber are not recommended for use in low-speed scenarios.
corpus.a8cd1476-75ff-45f6-8557-465ef1879d0f:
The underlying causes of these failures are as follows:
(1) Sealing failure can occur due to poor seal quality, incorrect assembly, damage, prolonged aging and deterioration over time, or incompatibility with the working medium.
(2) Relative motion between mating parts causes increased clearance and higher internal leakage, or can lead to scoring on the contact surfaces, resulting in both internal and external leaks.
(3) The oil temperature is too high.
(4) System operating pressure is too high.
(5) Incorrect design of sealing dimensions, poor machining accuracy, and improper assembly lead to internal and external leaks.
The repair method is as follows.
(1) Replace with high-quality seals.
(2) Adjust the clearances of the relative moving parts to ensure they fall within the normal range.
(3) Enhance cooling to maintain the oil temperature at an appropriate level.
(4) Adjust the system pressure to normal pressure.
(5) Redesign, manufacture, and assemble the seals.

Additionally, excessive clearance between mating components results in high internal and external leakage, causing substantial volumetric losses and rapid  temperature rise.
(3) The system is severely worn. Many key components in the hydraulic system rely on clearance sealing, such as the gears in gear pumps paired with the pump housi ng and side plates, the cylinder block and swashplate in piston pumps and motors, the cylinder bore fitting tightly around the pistons, the spool and valve body in directional cont rol valves, and the slide spools and valve sleeves/valve bodies in other types of valves. Once wear increases in these hydraulic components, it can lead to internal leakage.

Under normal operating conditions, mechanical equipment follows its own failure patterns; however, when operating conditions change, these failure patterns also shift accordingly. The primary operating conditions include the following:
(1) Load. The primary causes of wear and fatigue failure in mechanical equipment are the wear of components and their fatigue-induced damage. Under specified operating conditions, the rate of component wear over a given period is directly proportional to the magnitude of the load applied. Meanwhile, fatigue damage to components occurs only under certain types of cyclic loading and intensifies as the load increases. Thus, both wear and fatigue are functions of the applied load. Exceeding the design-rated load levels can lead to severe failure, which is unacceptable.
(2) Environment.

corpus.e8a9fc5b-af19-4636-9d3c-189a7b07f505:
2) Causes of Fluid Vibration
(1) Fluid vibration caused by the inherent flow pulsation of the hydraulic pump itself. In hydraulic systems, the hydraulic pump is the primary source of vibration, accounting for approximately 75% of the total system’s vibrational noise. Therefore, reducing the vibration of the hydraulic pump is a critical measure for improving product performance. Hydraulic pump flow pulsation is an intrinsic characteristic of the pump—particularly in axial piston pumps, where multiple pistons operate simultaneously, creating distinct oil-discharge and oil-suction chambers. As a result, the pump’s instantaneous flow rate at any given moment equals the sum of the instantaneous flows from all pistons currently in the discharge chamber. In other words, the output flow of an axial piston pump is essentially the superposition of individual sinusoidal flow patterns generated by each piston. For axial piston pumps, flow pulsation is directly tied to the pump’s operational design.
Inherent characteristics of plunger pumps: Hydraulic pumps with different numbers of plungers all exhibit corresponding inherent flow pulsations.

Meanwhile, the hydraulically actuated directional valve controls the reversing of the actuator elements within the system and is thus called the main valve.
This operating mechanism allows a small electromagnetic force to manage the high-flow switching of the main oil circuit, making it ideal for hydraulic systems requiring large flow rates. As shown in Figure 3.12(a), the structure of the electro-hydraulic directional valve features a three-position, four-way Y-type solenoid valve at the top as the pilot valve, while the main valve below is a three-position, four-way O-type hydraulically actuated directional valve.
The centering method for the spool of the three-position, four-way electro-hydraulic directional valve can be either spring-centered or hydraulically centered. When using spring-centering, the pilot valve should be a Y-type, three-position, four-way solenoid directional valve to ensure that, when the main spool is in the neutral position, the control oil chambers on both sides remain continuously connected to the reservoir, maintaining zero pressure.

4. Fit of Rolli ng Bearings
The bearing fit refers to the mating between the inner ring and the journal, as well as the outer ring and the housing, influencing the bearing's radial clearance, oper ational accuracy, and service life.
Rolling bearings are standard components, and the fit between the bearing bore and the shaft follows the hole basis system, while the fit betwee n the outer ring and the bearing housing uses the shaft basis system. Since the tolerance zone for the bearing inner diameter lies below the zero line, whereas in cylindrical toler ance standards, the tolerance zone for the reference hole is above the zero line, the interference fit between the inner ring and the journal is significantly tighter than the corr esponding hole-basis fits specified in cylindrical tolerance standards.

2. Electrochemical Corrosion o f Metal Parts
Electrochemical corrosion is a complex physical and chemical process of corrosion. It can be defined as the continuous, charge-driven chemical corrosion that occurs w hen two metal electrodes with a potential difference are immersed in an electrolyte solution. This type of corrosion happens when metals come into contact with electrolytic substan ces, and its key distinction from ordinary chemical corrosion lies in the fact that it involves the flow of electric current during the process.

As a result, these compromises often lead to reduced stability in low-level resolution—meaning the system becomes less precise, more prone to noise, and less reliable compared to directly connected setups.
Therefore, in low-level amplification circuits, it’s crucial to avoid using switches, connectors, and similar elements whenever possible. This practice is one of the most important strategies for minimizing failures and enhancing measurement accuracy.

2) Fatigue Crack Propagation Zone
This region is the most critical feature area on the fracture surface, often appearing shell-like or resembling beach ripples. Each individual line marks the trace left behind after a single crack extension event—typically corresponding to a change in applied load, such as when a machine starts up or shuts down. These lines radiate outward from the fatigue core, advancing perpendicularly to the direction of crack propagation. The smoother the crack propagation zone on the fatigue fracture surface, the more load cycles the component endured prior to failure.

By analyzing the fracture surface, it is possible to identify the primary cause of the fracture, providing valuable insights that help refine designs and enable effective repairs. Based on the cause of failure, fractures can be categorized into types such as brittle fracture and fatigue fracture.
Brittle Fracture
Before fracturing, the component exhibits no noticeable plastic deformation; this type of fracture, which develops extremely rapidly, is known as brittle fracture.  Brittle fracture occurs without any prior warning signs, making it a sudden and highly dangerous form of failure. Metal parts may become brittle—and thus prone to sudden fracture— due to improper manufacturing processes, exposure to corrosive media during use, or adverse environmental conditions. For instance, the penetration of hydrogen or hydrides into met al materials can lead to  "hydrogen embrittlement, " while chloride ions infiltrating austenitic stainless steel may cause  "chloride stress corrosion cracking. However, if the overload current is too high  or lasts for an extended period, it can cause the winding temperature to exceed safe levels, leading to insulation damage, reduced motor lifespan, and, in severe cases, even burni ng out the motor windings altogether. To fully utilize the motor's overload capacity while ensuring smooth starting and reliable operation—and to prevent winding overheating and su bsequent burnout—thermal relays are typically employed as overload protection devices for electric motors.
The commonly used thermal relay is of the bimetallic strip type, consisti ng primarily of a bimetallic strip, resistance wire (the heating element), and contacts. During operation, the heating element is connected in series with the motor's main circuit,  while the normally closed contacts are串联ed with the contactor coil in the control circuit. When the motor becomes overloaded, the normally closed contacts of the thermal relay ope n, cutting off the motor's control circuit and simultaneously disconnecting the main power supply.

1.5.1 The Significance of Equipment Management
Strengthening equipment management and ensuring proper maintenance will keep machinery consistently in excellent condition, thereby extending its lifespan. This not only plays a critical role in boosting production volume and variety, enhancing labor productivity, reducing consumption, lowering costs, and safeguarding worker safety—but also significantly contributes to upgrading the company’s overall production technology, accelerating industrial growth, and protecting productive capacity.
Equipment management is an extremely important task—only by effectively managing equipment can organizations achieve optimal economic results with minimal human, financial, and material resources. This, in turn, allows for the full realization of equipment potential, enabling businesses to better meet production goals. Especially in modern manufacturing, prioritizing sound equipment management is a fundamental principle that must be followed.
Equipment maintenance management is an important component of enterprise management.

Finally, rinse the bearing once more in gasoline before carefully placing it onto a clean piece of paper.
When cleaning spherical ball bearings and short cylindrical roller bearings, separate the balls, retainer cage, inner ring, and outer ring for individual cleaning. For bearings already mounted on a shaft, cleaning is typically done by pouring oil directly over them or using an oil gun for targeted spraying. 1.1.2 Classification of Failures
Mechanical and electrical equipment failures can be categorized from various perspectives, with each classification method highlighting a different aspect of the fault. The purpose of categorizing failures is to assess the severity of the incident, analyze its root causes, and ultimately enable more effective, tailored responses to address the specific types of malfunctions. By examining factors such as failure nature, underlying causes, and distinctive characteristics, faults can be grouped into the following categories.
By fault nature
(1) Intermittent failures. The equipment temporarily loses certain functions, with the faults often caused by external factors affecting the mechanical and electrical systems—such as operator error, climate changes, or inadequate environmental conditions. Once the external interference is removed or the equipment undergoes minor repairs and adjustments, its functionality typically resumes.
(2) Permanent failure. Once this type of failure occurs, it can only be restored through manual repair; otherwise, the fault will persist indefinitely. Such failures are typically caused by damage to specific components.

2) Hydraulic System Overheating Failure Repair Methods
To ensure the proper functioning of the hydraulic system, it i s essential to keep the system temperature within the normal range. If the hydraulic system overheats, first identify the underlying cause before implementing the appropriate and t argeted corrective measures.
(1) Select hydraulic oil according to the instructions in the hydraulic system manual, ensuring the oil remains clean to prevent filter clogging. Addit ionally, regularly check the oil level to maintain an adequate supply of hydraulic fluid.
(2) Regularly inspect and maintain wear-prone components to prevent leaks caused by severe  wear. Hydraulic pumps, electric motors, and areas with mating clearances are particularly susceptible to leakage due to wear, which can also lead to reduced volumetric efficiency  and accelerated system heating.

For instance, a thermistor may take several seconds to react to a step change in temperature, meaning it won’t instantly jump to a new impedance or produce an abrupt shift. Instead, it gradually adjusts to the new value over time. If a sensor with inherent delay characteristics attempts to respond rapidly to a sudden temperature change, the resulting output waveform will become distorted, as it will include dynamic error. Factors contributing to dynamic error include response time, amplitude distortion, and phase distortion.

This type of failure is most often caused by issues within the pressure regulation system itself. Possible reasons include: the damping orifice of the relief valve being blocked; foreign particles on the sealing surface of the relief valve; the main spool of the relief valve becoming stuck in the open position; the solenoid in the unloading directional control valve burning out, the wiring breaking, or the electrical signal failing to activate; and, in the case of proportional relief valves, the electric control signal may have been interrupted altogether.

corpus.65e1f8c4-684e-4360-b1ef-b7fb9a16f039:
Multifactorial and Correlation
The components of the equipment—and even individual devices—are interconnected through mechanical structures or material transfer. If one component or device fails, it can trigger malfunctions in other components or devices as well, highlighting the multifactorial and interconnected nature of failures. Therefore, when diagnosing the root cause of a malfunction, it’s essential to thoroughly consider all relevant factors involved.
Delayed Response
During operation, equipment components are continuously subjected to factors such as impact, stress, friction, wear, and corrosion, leading to vibrations, displacements, deformations, fatigue, and crack propagation. These processes gradually degrade the equipment's condition—until, at a certain point, the degradation becomes severe enough to result in mechanical malfunctions or even complete loss of functionality. The time-lag inherent in this failure progression underscores the importance of identifying potential issues early on and implementing preventive measures promptly, thereby minimizing the damage that could arise when a failure ultimately occurs.

For applications with large dimensions, heavy loads, significant vibrations, high r otational speeds, or elevated operating temperatures, a tighter fit is recommended. However, excessively tight fits can impair the bearing’s proper function and also make assembly  and disassembly more challenging. On the other hand, for components that require frequent removal or where the raceways experience movement, a looser fit should be chosen.
However,  excessive looseness is detrimental to improving bearing rotational accuracy and reducing vibration.

Hot disassembly leverages the thermal expansion properties of metals to separate parts, preventing issues like parts getting stuck or damaged—something that can occur with methods like impact or press disassembly. This technique is commonly used when the interference fit is significant (exceeding 0.1 mm), the components are large in size, or traditional disassembly methods prove impractical.

3. Classification of Common PLC System Faults
Common PLC system faults can generally be categorized into the following types, which can help people analyze where the failures occur.
Position and the reasons behind it.

(2) System failure. This is a wid espread malfunction that affects the overall operation of the system. System failures can be categorized into permanent faults and transient faults. If restarting the system after  the failure restores it to normal operation, the issue is classified as a transient fault.

2) Management Program
Maintenance technical documentation is primarily intended for use within the equipment management system and should generally be managed centrally in a dedicated documentation room. The management process should encompass the entire lifecycle of the materials—covering collection, organization, evaluation, classification, numbering, reproduction (such as drafting), storage, retrieval, and distribution. Effective management of technical documentation requires prioritization: key equipment manuals, along with relevant assembly drawings, electrical schematics, and other critical documents, should be clearly marked for enhanced oversight. Importantly, these priority documents are typically not available for external loan.
To facilitate compilation and retrieval, it is necessary to establish a coded indexing system for the data and implement computer-based management.

3) Transient Break Zone
Commonly referred to as the "static fracture surface," it is the fracture region formed when a fatigue crack rapidly propagates upon reaching a critical size. Its macroscopic features closely resemble the radial zone and shear lips typically observed in fast-fracture areas of static tensile fractures. The location and size of the instantaneous fracture zone are directly influenced by the applied load—specifically, the greater the load, the closer the final fracture area moves toward the center of the fracture surface. Conversely, a smaller fracture area indicates that the component was subjected to a lower load.

In fact, 70% to 80% of all hydraulic system failures are directly linked to contaminants present in the hydraulic oil, and among these oil-related failures, about 90% are attributed to impurities. Another significant cause of failure stems from natural wear, aging, and degradation that occur under normal operating conditions.
Impurities pose a serious threat to hydraulic systems, as they can accelerate component wear, increase leakage, impair system performance, and shorten component lifespan—even leading to equipment damage or complete system failure.
The following sections will focus on analyzing failures caused by improper design, manufacturing processes, incorrect usage practices, and hydraulic oil contamination.
Design rationale
When a hydraulic system malfunctions, the first step should generally be to analyze the rationality of its design. The design's suitability directly impacts the sy stem's operational performance, which becomes particularly evident during failure analysis of hydraulic systems in imported equipment.

The main equipment maintenance quotas include: equipment maintenance complexity factor, maintenance labor-hour quota, maintenance downtime quota, maintenance cycle and interval period, and maintenance cost quota.
1) Equipment Maintenance Complexity Factor
The equipment maintenance complexity factor, also known as the maintenance complexity unit or simply the maintenance unit, is a hypothetical measure used to assess the intricacy of equipment repair tasks, determine the associated workload, and establish standard benchmarks for various metrics. This assumed unit represents the maintenance effort required for a specific type of machinery, with its value determined by factors such as the equipment's structural design, dimensions, size, and precision levels. In general, the more complex the equipment's structure, the larger its physical dimensions, and the higher the machining accuracy demanded, the greater its maintenance complexity factor will be. For instance, in metal-cutting machine tools, the C620 lathe—typically featuring a maximum workpiece diameter of 400 mm and a maximum workpiece length of 1,000 mm—is often used as the benchmark machine. Its maintenance complexity factor is standardized at 10.

To ensure accurate temperature readings, thermocouples with a small time constant should be selected. The time constant is inversely proportional to the heat transfer coefficient and directly proportional to the diameter of the thermocouple's hot junction, as well as the material's density and specific heat. To minimize the time constant, the most effective approach—not only by enhancing the heat transfer coefficient—is to reduce the size of the hot junction as much as possible. In practice, protective sheaths made from materials with excellent thermal conductivity, featuring thin walls and small inner diameters, are commonly used.
4) Thermal Resistance Error
At high temperatures, if a layer of coal ash or dust adheres to the protective sheath, thermal resistance increases, impeding heat conduction. As a result, the temperature reading will be lower than the actual temperature being measured. Therefore, it’s important to keep the exterior of the thermocouple protective sheath clean.

Local Repair and Replacement Method
The localized repair and replacement method restores a part's functionality by addressing worn or damaged areas through techniques such as local repairs, adjustments, repositioning, or partial replacements.
4. Plastic Deformation Method
By leveraging the plastic deformation properties of metallic materials, this method allows excess material from non-functional areas of a part to be redistributed onto worn regions under specific external forces, thereby restoring the part’s original shape and dimensions. This approach not only alters the part’s geometry but also modifies its mechanical properties and microstructure. The primary techniques include upsetting, extrusion, expansion, and thermal straightening.
When repairing low-carbon steel or non-ferrous metal parts that have not undergone heat treatment, plastic deformation can be performed without heating. For medium- and high-carbon steel parts or alloy steel parts, heating is required during plastic deformation repair. In the case of quenched parts undergoing plastic deformation repair, they must first be subjected to high-temperature tempering or annealing.

The fundamental conditions necessar y for electrochemical corrosion to occur are: ① the presence of two or more objects with differing electrode potentials—or, within a single object, regions exhibiting different ele ctrode potentials—that act as positive and negative electrodes; ② a conductive pathway connecting the electrodes, either through a conductor or direct contact, allowing charges in  the corrosion zone to flow freely; and ③ the simultaneous presence of an electrolyte solution.
Common forms of electrochemical corrosion include the following:
(1) Uniform corrosio n. When a metal part or component exhibits a uniform corrosion pattern across its surface, it is referred to as uniform corrosion. This type of corrosion can occur in liquids, the  atmosphere, or soil. Among mechanical equipment, the most common form of uniform corrosion is atmospheric corrosion. In industrial areas, the atmosphere often contains higher conce ntrations of corrosive gases such as CO₂, SO₂, H₂S, NO₂, and Cl₂.

For instance, this phenomenon can be observed at interference or transition-fit interfaces between shafts and holes, on keyway  surfaces, or in threaded fasteners.

To prevent condensation from entering the compressed air system, it’s essential to promptly drain any accumulated moisture from all parts of the system.
The condensate drainage system encompasses the entire pneumatic system—from air compressors and aftercoolers, through air receivers and piping networks, all the way to individual air filters, dryers, and automatic drains. At the end of each workday, condensate should be drained from all points to prevent freezing when nighttime temperatures drop below 0°C. Additionally, as pipe temperatures continue to fall overnight, more condensate may form; therefore, it’s also essential to drain accumulated water before starting up equipment each morning. Regularly inspect automatic drains and dryers to ensure they’re functioning properly, and make sure to clean air filters and automatic drains on a routine basis.

In pneumatic systems, all surfaces with relative motion—from control components to actuator elements—require lubrication.

Maintenance Plan Development
1) Categories of Equipment Maintenance Plans
The time-phased plans include:
① The annual maintenance plan, which encompasses all major, medium, and minor repair schedules for the enterprise throughout the year, as well as regular equipment maintenance and upgrade/installation plans. This plan should be completed by the end of the previous year.
② The quarterly maintenance plan, derived from the annual plan, further breaks down the yearly objectives into more detailed tasks. It also allows for timely adjustments and additions to project timelines and sequences based on actual conditions, typically finalized during the last month of the preceding quarter.
③ The monthly maintenance plan, which is even more specific and meticulous than the quarterly plan, serves as the operational blueprint for executing maintenance activities. Critical tasks such as routine upkeep, periodic inspections, and scheduled diagnostics must all be incorporated into the monthly plan. Additionally, any issues identified during the previous month’s routine checks will be addressed by scheduling minor repairs this month.
Plans categorized by maintenance type usually consist of the annual major overhaul plan and the annual equipment preventive maintenance schedule.

1.3.4 Fracture of Mechanical Parts
Fracture refers to the phenomenon where a mechanical component develops localized cracks or splits into several parts under the influence of certain factors. It is one of the primary modes of mechanical component failure—once a part fractures, it not only completely loses its functionality but can also lead to significant economic losses and even cause accidents resulting in injuries or fatalities. Particularly as modern manufacturing systems continue to evolve toward higher power levels and faster rotational speeds, the operating conditions for components have changed dramatically, increasing the likelihood of fracture-related failures. As a result, fracture failure has become a hot topic of research today.
The fracture surface formed after a part breaks can accurately capture the dynamic evolution of the failure process.

When reversing the direction of rotation in a shunt motor with commutating poles, pay attention to the polarity of the commutating poles. If you reverse the direction of the armature current, the direction of the current in the commutating pole winding must also be reversed simultaneously. However, if you reverse the direction of the field winding current, neither the armature winding nor the commutating pole winding currents need to change.

1.1.1 Meaning of the Failure
Typically, a failure is defined as a condition in which a device (system) or component has lost its specified functionality. From a systems perspective, failure carries two key meanings: first, it refers to the mechanical system deviating from its normal function. The primary cause of this deviation lies in Chapter 1—Fundamentals of Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance for Electromechanical Equipment.
3
Work conditions (including components) are abnormal, and these types of failures can be resolved by adjusting parameters or repairing the affected parts, allowing the system to return to normal operation. The second scenario is functional failure, where the system continuously deviates from its intended performance, with the degree of deviation steadily worsening—eventually rendering the equipment unable to perform its basic functions. Such situations are classified as failures. Typically, failed individual components can be replaced; however, if critical components fail, it often results in the complete loss of the machine’s functionality.

Coil breakage typically results from overheating and subsequent burnout, though it can occasionally be caused by external physical damage.

1.1.2 Safety Measures for the Robot Body
When designing robots, unnecessary protrusions or sharp components should be eliminated, materials suitable for the working environment should be selected, and fail-safe protective structures should be incorporated to ensure the robot remains durable and prevents accidents during operation.
Additionally, to ensure safety, robots should be equipped with malfunction detection and shutdown features, as well as an emergency stop function, while also incorporating interlock mechanisms to prevent risks triggered by peripheral equipment.
When safety features or protective devices are turned off or removed, the robot must not operate.
When installing the included machine onto the end effector or robotic arm, strictly follow this manual and use the bolts specified in the manual—both in terms of type and quantity. Be sure to tighten them using a torque wrench to the exact torque setting provided.
Additionally, rusted or dirty bolts should not be used.
Failure to tighten according to the specified or improper methods will lead to bolt loosening, which could subsequently cause a serious accident.

As shown in Figure 3.14, the inlet pressure ( P_1 ) is reduced to ( P_2 ). When the spool is in its original position, the inlet and outlet remain fully open, keeping the valve in its normally open state. The control pressure for this valve is derived directly from the outlet.
When the outlet pressure ( P_2 ) rises to the setpoint value, the spool reaches its critical point of upward movement. If ( P_2 ) continues to increase beyond this point, the spool moves further upward, partially closing the valve port. This action increases the fluid resistance, leading to a greater pressure drop across the valve and, consequently, a reduction in the outlet pressure.

The vane motor boasts advantages such as a compact structure, small size, low inertia, minimal noise, reduced pulsation, long service life, and excellent low-speed performance. However, due to its relatively low output torque and limited resistance to contamination, it is primarily used in hydraulic systems of stationary machinery that require high speed but low torque—such as rotary tables in rubber and plastic processing equipment, light industrial machinery, and metal-cutting machine tools. It’s also commonly found in clamping and conveying mechanisms of automated production lines and machine tools, as well as in various hydraulic servo systems where low inertia is critical.
That said, vane motors are not suitable for use in mobile machinery operating under harsh environmental conditions.

Here are the precautions for using a hydraulically controlled check valve:
Ensure that the control pressure is sufficiently high to allow the hydraulically controlled check valve to open reliably in the reverse direction. Select the appropriate structural  design of the hydraulically controlled check valve based on its role within the system, its installation location, and the magnitude of flow resistance (backpressure) in the oil o utlet chamber when fluid flows in the reverse direction. Use either two hydraulically controlled check valves or a single bidirectional hydraulically controlled check valve to crea te a circuit that locks the hydraulic cylinder in place. During operation, the system flow rate must match the rated flow capacity of the hydraulically controlled check valve. Addi tionally, clearly identify the correct flow directions for the main ports, as well as the control and drain ports, to avoid improper installation.

2.5.5 Assembly and Adjustment of Bevel Gears
The assembly of a bevel gear transmission mechanism is essentially similar to that of a cylindrical gear transmission mechanism, with the key difference being that the axes of the two gears intersect at the apex of a cone, forming a specified angle. Typically, the geometric position of the bevel gear axes is determined by the machining accuracy of the housing, while axial positioning relies on the back cone of the bevel gear as a reference. During assembly, the back-cone surfaces must align precisely to ensure proper gear alignment. Depending on whether the contact pattern shifts toward the tooth tip or root, the gear positions should be adjusted and repositioned along the axis accordingly. Axial positioning is usually achieved by shims placed between the bearing housings and the housing itself. Since bevel gears are designed for transmitting motion between perpendicular shafts, the machining of the two vertical bearing housing bores in the housing must strictly adhere to the specified technical requirements.

(3) Piping, valves, and the oil tank. The piping itself is not a vibration source; rather, its vibrations are induced by the oscillations of other components. When the natural frequency of the piping matches the frequency of the vibration source, resonance occurs in the pipe, which can also trigger vibrations in adjacent components. Meanwhile, the oil tank itself generates vibrations as well. However, since the hydraulic pump and electric motor are directly mounted on the tank, their vibrations cause the tank to resonate, amplifying the overall vibration even further. Additionally, these vibrations may lead to turbulence within the oil tank, resulting in further oscillations of the hydraulic fluid.

Disassembling Threaded Connections
In mechanical equipment, threaded connections are the most widely used method of joining components. They offer advantages such as simple structure, convenient adjustment, and the ability to be repeatedly disassembled and reassembled. While these connections are relatively easy to dismantle, improper handling—such as insufficient attention, incorrect tool selection, or improper dismantling techniques—often leads to damage. Therefore, when removing threaded fasteners, it’s crucial to use the right wrench or screwdriver; always avoid using adjustable wrenches whenever possible. For particularly tough-to-remove threaded joints, first determine the direction of the thread rotation, and never force the connection by twisting randomly or applying excessive leverage with an overly long extension bar. When removing double-ended studs, always use a specialized wrench designed specifically for this purpose.
Disassembling Interference-Fit Components
When disassembling interference-fit components, select the appropriate removal method, tools, and equipment based on the part's fit dimensions and the size of the interference. Suitable options include pullers, presses, and other specialized tools.

5. Wiring Issues in PLC Systems
1) Requirements for on-site wiring
Taking Siemens PLCs as an example, the S7-200 PLC uses wires with a cross-sectional area of 0.5 to 1.5 mm². When wiring, it's best to use wires in pairs—pairing one neutral or common conductor with either a control wire or a signal wire. Additionally, keep AC lines separate from DC lines that carry large currents and experience rapid fluctuations, as well as from low-voltage signal lines. In cases of significant interference, be sure to install appropriate surge suppression devices.
2) PLC Grounding Issues
Good grounding is one of the measures to enhance PLC immunity against interference. When grounding a PLC, it's best to use a dedicated grounding wire.

2.4.6 Preloading in Rolling Bearing Assembly
Preloading refers to applying an axial load to the bearing during installation, inducing a slight pre-deformation between the rolling elements and the inner and outer rings, thereby enabling the bearing to operate with negative clearance.
Preloading increases bearing stiffness, enhances rotational accuracy, and extends bearing life.
The preload amount should be determined appropriately based on the bearing's load conditions and application requirements. Excessive preload, however, can increase bearing wear and heat generation, ultimately reducing the bearing's service life.
Preloading paired angular contact bearings can enhance their operational stiffness.

Precision diagnostic technology uses sophisticated instruments and methods to provide a detailed evaluation of equipment that is difficult to diagnose accurately with simpler techniques. It typically includes:

corpus.23a2c7bd-9a46-4fe3-813e-f18115c8e175:
Depending on the type of circuit being controlled, contactors are broadly classified into two main categories: AC contactors and DC contactors.
AC Contactor
An AC contactor is an electrical device that uses electromagnetic attraction combined with spring force to operate the closing and opening of its contacts. In control circuits for机电 equipment, it’s commonly used to connect or disconnect the power supply to motors and control circuits. The contactor primarily consists of an electromagnetic system and a contact system. The contact system includes main contacts and auxiliary contacts, while the electromagnetic system comprises components such as an electromagnetic coil, moving iron core, stationary iron core, and a return spring. The basic operation of electromagnetic attraction works as follows: When the electromagnetic coil is de-energized, the spring’s reaction force—or the moving iron core’s own weight—keeps the main contacts open. However, once the electromagnetic coil is connected to its rated voltage, the electromagnetic force overcomes the spring’s resistance, pulling the moving iron core toward the stationary iron core.

To ensure smooth equipment operation and safe production, implementing planned preventive maintenance is an essential component of equipment management and repair practices in industrial companies. This section will cover the detailed process of major equipment overhauls, the determination of equipment repair plans, as well as the technical and material preparations required prior to equipment maintenance.
1. Equipment Major Overhaul Process
To ensure the precision and operational performance of mechanical and electrical equipment, preventive scheduled maintenance must be carried out in addition to routine upkeep. Among these preventive measures, major overhauls stand out as a critical task aimed at restoring the equipment's accuracy. Within the category of preventive maintenance, major overhauls—often referred to simply as "overhauls"—represent the most extensive and time-consuming type of repair. An overhaul involves completely or largely disassembling the equipment, repairing or replacing foundational components, refurbishing mechanical and electrical parts, recalibrating the electrical systems, and finally reassembling and fine-tuning the entire unit. The ultimate goal is to thoroughly eliminate any pre-existing defects and restore the equipment to its specified performance standards.

In hydraulic syste ms, check valves are widely used—commonly installed at the ports of hydraulic pumps to prevent hydraulic oil from flowing backward. They’re also employed to isolate individual oil  circuits, ensuring that one circuit doesn’t interfere with another. Additionally, they can serve as backpressure valves or bypass valves.

4.4.2 Fault Analysis and Troubleshooting of Safety Valves
Structure and Working Principle of Safety Valves
The function of the safety valve is to vent to the atmosphere when the pressure in the pneumatic system rises to the set value, thereby maintaining the system pressure at that predetermined level. Figure 4.6 illustrates the structure and operating principle of a direct-acting relief valve. When the gas pressure in the system remains within the set range, the force acting on piston 3 is less than the force exerted by spring 2, keeping the piston in the closed position (see Figure 4.6(a)). However, once the system…
When the pressure rises and the force acting on the piston exceeds the spring's preset pressure, the piston moves upward, opening the valve to release air (see Figure 4.6(b)). The valve remains open until the system pressure drops below the set range, at which point the piston closes again. The magnitude of the opening pressure depends on
It relates to the spring's preload amount.

corpus.d98f8008-c366-40b4-9bb6-c6e1f5f9c12d: Specifically, this involves checking wh ether pressure and flow are within normal operating ranges, as well as verifying the status of critical auxiliary parameters such as system temperature and pump unit power. Under s pecific operating conditions, each component of hydraulic equipment typically maintains a stable set of values—meaning that when a hydraulic system is functioning correctly, its ke y operating parameters should remain close to their expected, condition-specific values. If the actual operating parameters of the hydraulic system deviate from these normal values  or show unusual fluctuations, it indicates that one or more components within the system may have malfunctioned. To diagnose the issue, simply measure the relevant operating param eters at designated monitoring points—such as temperature, pressure, flow rate, leakage, and power—and compare them against the system’s established normal operating values. This c omparison will help determine whether the system is running properly, identify any potential faults, and pinpoint the exact location of the problem.

3. Reliability Maintenance
Also known as Reliability-Centered Maintenance (RCM), this approach emerged in the U.S. civil aviation industry during the 1960s and is now widely implemented in industries with particularly high demands for equipment operational reliability, such as the nuclear and military sectors. While the time it takes for a potential failure in operating equipment to evolve into a functional failure can vary, all failure patterns eventually reveal detectable trends through systematic monitoring. This technique leverages these predictable patterns to implement proactive maintenance measures—making it a reliability-focused maintenance strategy aimed at enhancing equipment dependability.

Consequently, electrical faults in机电 equipment primarily occur in these two types of devices. The spray welding repair technique can effectively enhance and improve the performance of part surfaces, such as oxidation resistance, electrical conductivity, insulation properties, and thermal insulation. However, the bond strength of the sprayed coating is relatively low, so caution should be exercised during application.
Spray welding repair can restore the dimensions of worn components, such as machine tool spindles, crankshafts, camshaft journals, motor rotor shafts, machine tool guides, and slides. It can also be used to repair defects in castings, like sand holes and porosity. Additionally, applying a wear-resistant material—such as phosphor bronze or aluminum bronze—to areas requiring enhanced durability can significantly improve the component's resistance to wear. Meanwhile, spraying protective coatings onto specific areas can boost the part's corrosion resistance and other performance characteristics.

The main methods of surface heat treatment include flame quenching and induction heating, while common heat sources include flames such as oxy-acetylene or oxy-propane, as well as induced currents, lasers, and electron beams.
(2) Surface chemical heat treatment strengthening.
Surface chemical heat treatment is a metal heat treatment process that alters the chemical composition, microstructure, and properties of a workpiece's surface layer. Unlike surface heat treatment, which primarily modifies the material's surface properties through temperature changes, surface chemical heat treatment specifically targets the chemical composition of the surface layer.
Chemical heat treatment involves heating a workpiece in a medium containing carbon, nitrogen, or other alloying elements—such as gas, liquid, or solid—and holding it at that temperature for an extended period. This process allows elements like carbon, nitrogen, boron, and chromium to diffuse into the surface of the workpiece. After diffusion, additional heat treatment processes, such as quenching and tempering, may be carried out as needed.

If the hydraulic oil remains clear, transparent, and colorless, it indicates that the oil is free from contamination.
If the oil appears cloudy and white, with clarity at the top of the bottle and turbidity at the bottom, it suggests that water has entered and contaminated the oil. Conversely, if the oil is clear at the bottom but cloudy at the top, air has likely mixed in, causing contamination.
If the oil turns a mottled, unevenly cloudy reddish-brown hue, it means iron rust and sediment have contaminated the fluid.
A deep red or tea-brown color signals that the oil has degraded due to high temperatures and oxidation.
If the oil remains transparent but has faded in color, it suggests that an incompatible type of oil has been mixed in—but as long as the viscosity still meets specifications, the oil can still be used.

1. Structure and Working Principle of the Flow Valve
As shown in Figure 4.8, this is a diagram illustrating the structure and operating principle of a flow valve, which is composed of a one-way valve and a throttle valve combined into a single unit. It is commonly used as a speed control valve for cylinders. The throttle valve features a needle-type orifice: when air flows in through port A, it lifts the one-way valve open, allowing airflow to exit from port O; however, when air enters through port P, the one-way valve closes, forcing the airflow to pass through the throttling orifice before exiting from port P.

5. Fault Diagnosis and Maintenance of Pressure Surges in Hydraulic Systems
Hydraulic shock is one of the common failures. In hydraulic transmission systems, the pressure of the fluid inside the system can suddenly fluctuate at a specific moment due to rapid directional changes or the abrupt opening or closing of valve ports.
1) Causes of hydraulic shock
(1) Sudden closure or opening of a valve. When a liquid flows through a pipe, if the valve is closed abruptly, the flow velocity instantly drops to zero. At this moment, the liquid's kinetic energy is converted into pressure energy, causing a sudden increase in fluid pressure and generating a pressure shock wave. Conversely, when the valve opens suddenly, a drop in pressure occurs instead.
(2) Inertial forces of actuators.

Surface Enhancement Technologies
Surface enhancement technology refers to a process that modifies the microstructure and properties of a part's surface, making them distinct from those of the base material. This technique can significantly improve the surface’s hardness, strength, wear resistance, and corrosion resistance. Specifically, it includes several methods such as surface mechanical strengthening, surface heat treatment strengthening, chemical heat treatment strengthening, laser surface treatment, and electrical discharge machining-based surface enhancement.
Surface Mechanical Strengthening
Surface mechanical strengthening involves inducing compressive deformation in the metal surface of a part through methods such as shot peening, roll forming, and internal extrusion, creating a hardened layer measuring 0.3 to 1.5 mm in thickness on the surface.
Shot peening involves blasting high-velocity projectiles onto a component's surface, inducing intense plastic deformation in the metal material and creating a cold-worked layer with elevated residual stresses—known as the shot-peened layer.
Shot peening enhances a material's resistance to fatigue fracture, preventing fatigue failure, plastic deformation, and brittle fracture while extending its fatigue life.

4) Diagnostic Decision-making
Based on the assessment of the equipment's current status, determine the appropriate responses and actions to take. At the same time, forecast how the equipment's condition may evolve based on existing signals, and conduct a trend analysis to anticipate future developments.
The above four steps form a cycle; often, a complex or challenging fault cannot be correctly identified in just one cycle. Instead, it requires multiple iterations of the diagnostic process (as shown in Figure 1.1), gradually deepening both your understanding and the accuracy of your assessments—only then can the issue ultimately be resolved.
Figure 1.1: Fault Diagnosis Process
Equipment Fault Diagnosis Levels
Equipment fault diagnosis is generally divided into two levels: simple diagnosis and precision diagnosis. Most equipment faults can be identified using simple diagnostic techniques, making this approach the foundation of diagnostic work. Precision diagnostic techniques are only employed when simple diagnostics fail to pinpoint the issue.
Simple Diagnostic Technique
Simple diagnostic techniques involve using straightforward instruments and methods to quickly provide a general assessment of equipment condition.

If the handle of directional control valve 6 is moved to the left, as shown in Figure 3.1(b), the oil pressed into the left chamber of the worktable hydraulic cylinder via directional control valve 6 will be drained back to the oil tank 1 through the same valve. First, there must be proper fit requirements. The tolerance limits for the clearance include the initial clearance that remains after assembly and running-in. If the initial clearance is too large, the effective service life will be shortened. Additionally, the positional accuracy between individual components during assembly is critical—failure to meet these specifications can lead to additional stresses, uneven wear, and ultimately accelerate component failure.

Following the principles of process rationality, cost-effectiveness, and production feasibility, carry out repairs in a sensible manner to ensure high-quality outcomes.

The device in question is an electrical component designed to automatically or manually alter the state or parameters of a circuit, enabling functions such as controlling, protecting, measuring, indicating, regulating, and converting circuits or controlled objects. It serves as the most fundamental element in constructing low-voltage control circuits. Commonly used low-voltage electrical appliances include protective low-voltage control devices, such as fuses and residual current devices; control devices like contactors, relays, solenoid valves, and electromagnetic brakes; and master command devices, including universal transfer switches, push buttons, and limit switches.
5.5.1 Contactor
A contactor is an electrical device used to automatically switch large-current circuits on or off. It can frequently connect or disconnect AC and DC circuits and enables remote control.

1) On-site recording and photography
After a major equipment accident occurs, promptly investigate and understand all circumstances before and after the incident, and take photographs or videos if necessary. Unless there are casualties requiring immediate attention, efforts should be made to preserve the scene as much as possible.
2) Analyze the dominant failure component
When a critical component fails due to fracture, it often leads to the failure of other related parts and structural elements. In such cases, it’s essential to carefully determine the sequence of events and accurately identify the primary fracture-causing component—otherwise, the analysis results could be misleading.
3) Identify the dominant crack on the primary failure component
The dominant failure component may already be fragmented; therefore, the remaining fragments should be collected, carefully pieced together, and analyzed to identify which crack initiated first—this crack is the dominant one.
4) Identifying the Failure Source Area
Once the dominant crack is identified, you can then examine the corresponding fracture surface to locate the crack initiation zone.

Alternatively, if the motor takes too long to start, the heating element may carry the starting current for an extended period . Both scenarios can lead to false tripping of the thermal relay. For the first case, motor startups should be limited or a semiconductor thermistor temperature relay could be used  instead. In the second scenario, measures can be implemented in the control circuit—such as short-circuiting the thermal relay during startup—to allow the motor to run normally af ter the initial start-up phase.
② An error (tending to be lower) in the thermal relay’s current adjustment scale can lead to false tripping. In this case, follow the steps below fo r proper adjustment: First, turn the current-adjustment cam toward the higher-current setting, then restart the equipment. After the equipment has been running normally for about 1  hour, slowly adjust the current-adjustment cam back toward the lower-current setting until the thermal relay trips. Finally, gently rotate the adjustment cam further toward the hi gher-current side to fine-tune the setting.

(3) Step-by-Step Tracking Method. The step-by-step tracking method for fault detection involves dividing the entire system’s control process into several discrete control steps. By checking whether the interlocking conditions between these steps are met, this method identifies potential faults within the system. Specifically, if a fault occurs during any particular step, the program halts at that point and automatically switches to the fault-detection routine. This routine then systematically evaluates all interlocking conditions associated with the faulty step, pinpointing the exact source of the issue and alerting maintenance personnel to carry out the necessary repairs. This approach is particularly suited for sequential control systems where operational steps are clearly defined and the control process can be paused temporarily—but it does require relatively complex programming.

Gas welding
A welding method that uses the flame generated by the combustion of a flammable gas mixed with an oxidizing gas as a heat source, melting both the workpiece and the filler material to achieve atomic-level bonding. The primary oxidizing gas is oxygen, while common flammable gases include acetylene, liquefied petroleum gas, and others.
Oxygen-acetylene gas welding equipment primarily includes oxygen cylinders, acetylene cylinders (if acetylene is used as the combustible gas), pressure regulators, welding torches, and hoses. Since the gas cylinders used to store these flammable and explosive gases are pressure vessels, this method is one of the most hazardous among all welding techniques.
Advantages of gas welding: simple equipment, flexible use; excellent adaptability for welding cast iron and certain non-ferrous metals; and a valuable option when welding is needed in areas with insufficient power supply.

First, it provides strong adhesion and can bond dissimilar materials  together. Second, the process operates at relatively low temperatures, preventing thermal deformation of the bonded materials. Third, after bonding, the integrity and surface fini sh of the original components remain intact, with no stress concentrations formed. Additionally, the adhesive joint exhibits excellent chemical stability, insulation properties, an d sealing performance. Finally, the bonding process is simple, cost-effective, and allows for quick repair times.
The drawback of the bonding process is that it lacks high-temperat ure resistance—organic adhesives typically can only withstand long-term operation up to 150°C.
Inorganic adhesives can withstand high temperatures of up to 700°C; however, they exh ibit poor impact resistance and aging performance. Compared to welding, their bonding strength is relatively low. 7
Consideration: Imperfect design solutions and inadequate review of design drawings and technical documents are major causes of failures.
2) Material Selection
In design, manufacturing, and maintenance, it is essential to correctly select materials based on the nature and characteristics of the part’s function. Improper material selection, failure to meet specified material standards, or the use of inappropriate substitutes are major causes of phenomena such as wear, corrosion, excessive deformation, fatigue, cracking, and aging. Additionally, during manufacturing and repair processes, many materials undergo various fabrication steps, including casting, forging, welding, and heat treatment. Throughout these processes, the microstructure and mechanical/physical properties of the materials often undergo significant changes—among which the effects of heating and cooling are particularly critical.
3) Manufacturing Quality
Errors exist in every step of the manufacturing process.

4. Quality Maintenance
This is an equipment maintenance procedure developed with a focus on ensuring product quality, aiming to keep all critical quality characteristics of product components and parts in optimal condition. 5.5.4 Control Devices
Main command devices include buttons, limit switches, master controllers, and more. These devices control the operation of other electrical equipment by opening or closing circuits, effectively "issuing" commands for electrical control. By using main command devices, it’s possible to perform operations on control circuits as well as implement sequential control. Common faults and repair methods for each type of main command device are outlined below.
1. Button
